articles.headline: Digital Sales Surpass CDs at Atlantic
articles.snippet: Atlantic is the first major label to report getting a majority of its revenue from digital sales, not CDs.
articles.abstract: Atlantic is the first major label to report getting a majority of its revenue from digital sales, not CDs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since MP3s first became popular a decade ago, music industry executives have obsessed over this question: when would digital music revenue finally surpass compact disc sales?

articles.headline: A Global Downturn Puts the Brakes on China’s Industry
articles.snippet: The global downturn is reaching deep into the heart of the country’s once-rapid industrial transformation.
articles.abstract: The global downturn is reaching deep into the heart of the country’s once-rapid industrial transformation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MA’ANSHAN, China  The Ma’anshan Iron and Steel Company recently opened a giant $3 billion steel mill on the outskirts of this city. The mill, which covers one and a half square miles and has its own power plant and shipping port, was built to help meet China’s seemingly insatiable appetite for growth.

articles.headline: Extreme Makeover at Morgan Stanley
articles.snippet: The former investment bank, now a bank holding company, plots its future.
articles.abstract: The former investment bank, now a bank holding company, plots its future.

articles.headline: Study Cites Toll of AIDS Policy in South Africa
articles.snippet: Thabo Mbeki’s government could have prevented the premature deaths of 365,000 people, a new study says.
articles.abstract: Thabo Mbeki’s government could have prevented the premature deaths of 365,000 people, a new study says.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  A new study by Harvard researchers estimates that the South African government would have prevented the premature deaths of 365,000 people earlier this decade if it had provided antiretroviral drugs to AIDS patients and widely administered drugs to help prevent pregnant women from infecting their babies.

articles.headline: Obama Plans to Retain Gates at Defense Department
articles.snippet: President-elect Barack Obama will keep Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates as a show of continuity in a time of war, Democrats close to the transition said.
articles.abstract: President-elect Barack Obama will keep Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates as a show of continuity in a time of war, Democrats close to the transition said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama has decided to keep Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates in his post, a show of bipartisan continuity in a time of war that will be the first time a Pentagon chief has been carried over from a president of a different party, Democrats close to the transition said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: To Buy Children’s Gifts, Mothers Do Without
articles.snippet: Parents, especially mothers, are putting off personal spending to buy their children the latest toys.
articles.abstract: Parents, especially mothers, are putting off personal spending to buy their children the latest toys.
articles.lead_paragraph: Come Christmas, McKenna Hunt, a gregarious little girl from Safety Harbor, Fla., will receive the play kitchen and the Elmo doll she wants. But her mother, Kristen Hunt, will go without the designer jeans she covets this season.

articles.headline: The Return of Larry Summers
articles.snippet: Over the last two years, Lawrence Summers has carved out a role as a shadow economic minister, laying out how a Democratic administration would have responded to the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Over the last two years, Lawrence Summers has carved out a role as a shadow economic minister, laying out how a Democratic administration would have responded to the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Remorseful Ex-Officials Decline Pay From UBS
articles.snippet: Three former officials of UBS, the troubled Swiss financial giant, said that they would forgo more than $27 million in compensation.
articles.abstract: Three former officials of UBS, the troubled Swiss financial giant, said that they would forgo more than $27 million in compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a number of American banks resist calls to rein in executive pay, the unthinkable is happening  at least in Switzerland, where three former officials of UBS, the troubled Swiss financial giant, said on Tuesday that they would forgo more than $27 million in compensation.

articles.headline: Beyond the Ivied Halls, Endowments Suffer
articles.snippet: Some of the nation’s universities are trying to sell chunks of their portfolios privately as their endowments swoon with the markets.
articles.abstract: Some of the nation’s universities are trying to sell chunks of their portfolios privately as their endowments swoon with the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s universities are trying to sell chunks of their portfolios privately as their endowments swoon with the markets.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Geraldine Fabrikant
